item.title: Russia and China are expanding in the Arctic: Europe needs a new plan for the region
item.description:
Russia and China are expanding in the Arctic: Europe needs a new plan for the region Expert comment LToremark 3 October 2025

As the thawing Arctic’s geostrategic importance grows, military and economic objectives are becoming increasingly intertwined.

Russian expansionism in the Arctic is increasingly becoming a key security challenge for Europe. Despite much of Russia’s resources being used for the war in Ukraine, the Kremlin has continued to invest heavily in building out its presence and revamping its existing bases in the Arctic. The region is becoming a hotbed for hybrid activity. Russia sealed off large swathes of the Barents Sea, including parts of Norway’s exclusive economic zone, for its most recent Zapad-2025 exercises with Belarus, and practised cruise missile launches over the Arctic.

Related work

Exploring military security issues in the Arctic

European countries and their NATO allies have started to push back more forcefully. The accession of Sweden and Finland to NATO means that the alliance now counts seven of the eight traditional Arctic states as members – a development Moscow has described as a ‘hostile encirclement’. Over the past few months, NATO ships have repeatedly patrolled deep into the Barents Sea – near the home of Russia’s Northern Fleet and key nuclear submarine base. And, like Russia, NATO too is investing in rebuilding and updating military infrastructures in the region.

But security in the Arctic is about more than naval presence and counting submarines. Military and economic objectives are becoming increasingly intertwined as the thawing Arctic’s geostrategic importance grows and competing powers scramble to seize its resources and benefit from new commercial trade routes. As European NATO members grow their military presence in the Arctic and try to bolster their geostrategic heft in the region, they must also become more strategic about growing their wider economic footprint.  

Presence equals sovereignty 

‘The EU’s self-sufficiency and independence from Russia and China will begin in the [Arctic] mine’, said Sweden’s then-energy minister Ebba Busch in 2023, while hosting European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in the Arctic town of Kiruna – home to Europe’s largest known deposit of iron ore as well as significant rare earth supplies. 

The Arctic may well hold part of the answer to Europe’s quest to reduce its external resource dependencies. But Europe has so far been slow to develop these opportunities and investment has been lagging. While some of this hesitation reflects extremely valid concerns – exploiting the Arctic must not come at an environmental cost or undermine indigenous rights – it has helped open the door to actors with fewer scruples, such as China.

And it is not just about economic opportunity costs: in the sparsely populated Arctic, physical presence equals control and sovereignty. This also carries serious security risks. Infrastructure roll-out in the Arctic is by virtue almost always dual-use, which allows the countries that own these assets to also increase their security position in this highly strategic region. 

China has used research collaboration – including with European countries – and investments in things like Arctic research stations and space infrastructure to add credibility to its claim that it is a near-Arctic power (despite its most northernmost provincial capital, Harbin, being as far from the Arctic as Venice). European countries have only recently woken up to not just the geopolitical influence that such arrangements can afford Beijing – but also their security implications. 

A polar silk road

Another such example is the development of the Northern Sea Route (NSR), connecting Asia and Europe by way of Russia. As the thawing Arctic becomes more accessible for commercial traffic, the NSR – which could reduce shipping time by as much as half – could become a new nerve centre of global trade. While many practical hurdles remain, Russia and China are both bent on seizing the economic opportunity these new routes have to offer. 

The current (still modest) use of the route is primarily used for crude oil and LNG shipments from Russia to China, especially since the start of Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine. But Beijing’s bigger and longer-term ambition is centred around new shipping routes for its goods to Europe – that provides Europe with leverage and the ability to have a say in how these new routes should develop. 

Related work

Trump is pushing Europe and China closer together. Europe should tread carefully

Europe must use this leverage and not allow Russia to develop the NSR on its (and Beijing’s) terms. The Russian Arctic is already becoming a hotbed for shadow fleet activity, used to evade Western oil sanctions. Moscow’s ambition to control the NSR has also increasingly taken on a military dimension.  

In the longer term, the increased navigability of the NSR will present an important litmus test for how Europe wants to handle (and exploit potential fractures in) the China–Russia partnership, as well as its own evolving security and economic relationship with China. 

Greater presence also equals new targets

Europe is also building its own new connections to Asia. The European Commission is supporting the scoping of a what would be the first major undersea communications cable through the Arctic, connecting Europe to North America and East Asia. This could reduce internet traffic travel time by as much as 40 per cent compared to the currently dominant – but much longer and increasingly insecure – Red Sea cable routes. The project is intended to bring more diversity and security to Europe’s communications links and help Europe bolster its presence in the Arctic.

This highly ambitious project is a good example of how security and economic concerns intersect. The cable would have a significant dual-use utility and could help bring high-speed, high-capacity connectivity to power NATO’s military infrastructure and space-based assets in the High North. It would however also create another target for possible attacks.

item.title: Top 10 Books: International Women’s Day 2025
item.description:
To mark International Women’s Day this year, the official celebratory website asks us to ‘Imagine a gender equal world … A world where difference is valued and celebrated.’ This might feel like an arduous, if not utopian, demand on creativity, in a world where the far right is on the rise and women’s rights are increasingly encroached upon. For anyone in need of inspiration, Book Reviews Editor Mariana Vieira has curated a selection of outstanding books written by women that have been reviewed in the journal over the past year. As will become apparent to those who read further, this list is also partly a celebration of the women of International Affairs, who have contributed to our diverse research offering over the years. Find out what this means below.

1) The micro-sociology of peace and conflict

Written by Isabel Bramsen. Published in Cambridge by Cambridge University Press.

Isabel Bramsen’s 2022 article in International Affairs drew on peace talks in the Philippines to argue that diplomatic meetings can generate social bonds between conflicting parties. In her latest book, The micro-sociology of peace and conflict, Bramsen has expanded on the scope of the article’s insights, engaging with ‘micro-moments’ from the peace talks in the Philippines and Northern Ireland, to the everyday interactions at West Bank checkpoints and the reciprocal violence of the Arab Spring uprisings. Armed with an auspicious theoretical framework and a focus on video footage analysis, the author showcases how the micro-dynamics of different interactions can (de-)energize participants and lead to varying degrees of bonding or tension, which ultimately exemplify the relevance of micro-sociological approaches in IR.

Read the full review here.

2) The women of the far right

Written by Eviane Leidig. Published in New York by Columbia University Press.

If Cynthia Enloe was to delve into the literature on far-right radicalization and ask: ‘Where are the women?’, Eviane Leidig’s book would provide the answer. The women of the far right presents a multifaceted analysis of north American ‘influencers’ and the online spaces they occupy and instrumentalize. Leidig details how these women have sought to make far-right movements relatable and to generate socio-political acceptance of their ideologies. The book offers many new insights, exploring how these influencers were radicalized themselves, shedding light on the business and lifestyle dimensions of their online radicalization activities and contextualizing their impact within wider transnational networks.

Read the full review here.

3) Inside the UN Security Council

Written by Jess Gifkins. Published in Oxford by Oxford University Press.

The war in Darfur, Sudan, lasted almost three decades and many have asked what international society could have done differently. Inside the UN Security Council critically appraises how the UNSC’s decision-making processes and questions of legitimacy dictated its approach to the conflict in Darfur. Jess Gifkins, who has previously written for International Affairs on the importance of queering the Responsibility to Protect doctrine, turns here to the importance of informal, unwritten legitimation practices within the UNSC. The book will appeal to a wide audience, as it illustrates the previously underplayed role of the ten non-permanent members, challenges rational models that overlook when actors choose to take action for optics and points to the implications of China’s increasing influence.

Read the full review here.

4) Autocracy, Inc.

Written by Anne Applebaum. Published in London by Allen Lane.

Anne Applebaum’s latest book indicts both the autocratic leaders with global ambitions and the western politicians and kleptocrats that enable and profit from the activities of the former. Autocracy, Inc. combines a fascinating account of how the autocrat’s involvement in sanctions-busting, arms trade and drug-dealing, combined with an eye-opening description of the ways in which a host of western banks, lawyers, real-estate agents and media sympathizers have lined their pockets with the profits from money-laundering activities. While Applebaum rounds off the book with suggestions for financial regulations and ‘de-risking’, readers are not advised to skip ahead, as this well-researched wake-up call should be thoroughly digested.

Read the full review here.

5) The uncertainty doctrine

Written by Alexandra Homolar. Published in Cambridge by Cambridge University Press.

In this fresh and ambitious take on the role of narratives in US foreign policy, Alexandra Homolar questions why the end of the Cold War brought about many changes to the international arena but spelled continuity for US security strategy. The author yields her archive-based chapters impressively to demonstrate the messiness of narratives, despite IR scholars’ wishes and efforts to impose order on them. Resorting to illustrative metaphors, the book demonstrates how US foreign policy elites built a post-Cold War security narrative through a process of entanglement and negotiation, as opposed to developing a masterminded vision. Watch out for the budget-friendly paperback launch this month!

Read the full review here.

6) Cosmopolitan elites

Written by Kira Huju. Published in Oxford by Oxford University Press.

Connoisseurs of Kira Huju’s 2022 International Affairs article, ‘Saffronizing diplomacy: the Indian Foreign Service under Hindu nationalist rule’, will find Huju’s first book eminently rewarding. In Cosmopolitan elites, Huju picks up the Indian Foreign Service (IFS) once again, to expose how class, caste, gender and religion shape its composition. The author brings in everyday practices and domestic hierarchies to illustrate the exclusionary codes that dictate participation in international society. The book benefits from a broad historical scope that allows Huju to document the enduring tension between the influence of colonial ideals and the aspirations of a postcolonial India.

Read the full review here.

7) PeaceTech

Written by Christine Bell. Published in Cham, Switzerland by Springer.

In this open-access and timely book, Christine Bell re-energizes the debate on how emerging technologies can be deployed in conflict and peacebuilding settings. Bell warns against the appeal of ‘shiny new things’ and questions the assumption that digital innovation can automatically improve peacebuilding practices. The author explores the drivers behind the agendas and investment decisions that shape peacebuilding endeavours. Equally candid and inspirational, the book puts forward a twelve-step manifesto on ensuring that digital tools support peace processes. As a long-time practitioner and scholar, Bell is well placed to provide insights that will benefit anyone interested in the digitization of contemporary dynamics of peace.

Read the full review here.

8) Governing the feminist peace

Written by Paul Kirby and Laura J. Shepherd. Published in New York by Columbia University Press.

Beyond its brilliantly illustrated cover, this co-authored book has a much wider appeal. Paul Kirby and Laura Shepherd have teamed up for a provocative and convincing critique of the Women, Peace and Security (WPS) agenda, as a product of specific global governance frameworks. Deploying some impressive empirical research, Governing the feminist peace persuasively highlights the incoherent, contested and contingent nature of the WPS discourse, particularly as it features in the fields of policy and governance. In the words of our reviewer: ‘forgetting WPS, in the way that Kirby and Shepherd suggest, might provide an opportunity to expand the ethical imaginaries of war and peace’.

Read the full review here.

9) Reluctance in world politics

Written by Sandra Destradi. Published in Bristol by Bristol University Press.

Last year, our November issue featured a highly popular special section on ‘The effects of global populism’, guest-edited by Sandra Destradi with Daniel F. Wajner and Michael Zürn. As a multifaceted scholar, Destradi’s most recent book before that sought to explain why powerful states fail to act decisively in the face of crises within their spheres of influence. To explain this phenomenon, the author offers a new and multidimensional theory of reluctance that breaks with the idea that ‘reluctant hegemons’ are unwilling to lead. Destradi compares the case-studies of Brazil, Germany and India, illustrating their policy choices through an impressive combination of expert interviews and policy analysis.

Read the full review here.

10) Police peacekeeping

Written by Lou Pingeot. Published in New York and Oxford by Oxford University Press.

In Police peacekeeping, Lou Pingeot tackles the United Nations’ deployment of police units in its peace operations through the case-study of the UN mission in Haiti (2004–17). This impressive feat of ethnographic and interdisciplinary research traces the emergence of peacebuilding and global policing, offering a stark reminder of their colonial histories: policing models designed to pacify the populations deemed as a risk to social orders are deployed abroad with important implications for the global social order. In the words of our reviewer, this book is ‘essential reading for those researching and developing policy guidance for peacekeeping, military and humanitarian interventions, as well as for those interested in the reproduction of global inequalities’.

Read the full review here.

Mariana Vieira is the Book Reviews Editor of International Affairs.

item.title: Top 10 books: The International Affairs Christmas reading list 2024
item.description:
The holidays offer the perfect excuse to read a book from cover to cover and our Christmas reading list has excellent suggestions for the international relations enthusiast. This year, Book Reviews Editor Mariana Vieira was inspired by the regional spread of the books reviewed for the journal and this hand-picked selection spotlights a wide range of locales, from Australia, Cuba, Egypt and Haiti, to India, Iran, Tanzania and Uganda. And because diversity is not simply a matter of geography, the books featured also vary thematically, speaking to issues of defence, interventionism, gender, postcolonial imaginations and more!

1) The unfinished quest

Written by T.V. Paul. Published in New York by Oxford University Press.

In The unfinished quest, T.V. Paul examines India’s pursuit of great power status since it gained its independence in 1947. The book combines a historical view of origins, causes and drivers with an assessment of the country’s hard and soft power capabilities, including its domestic and international practices. Paul points to how the gap between India’s status ambitions and its material capabilities to achieve them is closing. Despite its promising progress, Paul contends that India must address certain human development challenges before it can achieve the greater recognition that it seeks. An excellent read, utterly timely and accessible.

Read the full review here.

2) What really went wrong

Written by Fawaz A. Gerges. Published in New Haven, CT by Yale University Press.

Speaking of regional and distinguished veterans with a regional expertise, Fawaz A. Gerges’s latest book spotlights the West’s destabilizing role in the Middle East. The author argues that US interventions at the height of the Cold War largely contributed to the regional ‘failure of democracy’. The book features case-studies of Iran and Egypt, exploring the CIA’s toppling of Iran’s elected Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh in 1953 and the US’ alienation of Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser. Gerges’s useful and tactful counterfactual approach to the ‘seeds of instability’ prompts readers to reflect on the political trajectories of both countries and on the realm of possibilities that western interventionism foreclosed in the region.

Read the full review here.

3) Intervention before interventionism

Written by Patrick Quinton-Brown. Published in Oxford by Oxford University Press.

In this feat of genealogical prowess, Singapore-based Patrick Quinton-Brown traces and problematizes the origins and development of the concept of intervention in international relations. Drawing on a wealth of archival research, the book navigates the post-1945 debates on interventionism, sovereignty and self-determination, displacing the mainstream Westphalian discourses and recovering the global South perspectives and contributions. Our Review Forum on Intervention before interventionism offers an instructive, careful and inspiring dialogue on the book’s aims to lay out ‘a series of alternatives at a time when non-intervention, quite suddenly, seems everywhere’. Explore contributions from Robbie Shilliam, Jennifer M. Welsh and more below.

Read the Review Forum here.

4) Our comrades in Havana

Written by Radoslav Yordanov. Published in Stanford, CA by Stanford University Press.

While existing research focuses largely on the Soviet–Cuban bilateral ties, Our comrades in Havana reveals the ‘complex and often adversarial relationship between the various actors’ without losing sight of Cuba’s agency and its international activism. Radoslav Yordanov foregrounds Cuba’s relationships with the Soviet bloc through a series of chronological events, including Cuba’s formal entrance and subsequent economic dependence on the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance. Yordanov’s dedication to recently declassified records from eastern European states allows the author to detail developments such as Cuba’s disappointment with the lack of support for its active role in the Third World and East Germany’s contributions to Cuba’s intelligence capabilities. This book broadens the horizons of Cold War historiography and whets the appetite of global history enthusiasts.

Read the full review here.

5) The face of the nation

Written by Elise Stephenson. Published in Oxford by Oxford University Press.

The face of the nation integrates historical institutional analysis with women’s narratives to investigate the extent, nuance and dynamics of gender discrimination and sexism within the sphere of Australian international affairs. In it, Elise Stephenson, the deputy director of the Global Institute for Women’s Leadership, focuses on different institutions and pays special attention to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT). While women’s representation within the DFAT has increased, the institution is shrinking in power and funding as other defence agencies are expanding. The book’s dozens of interviews with women in senior positions, including Australia’s first female prime minister, Julia Gillard, will also benefit anyone interested in diplomacy and women’s experiences.

Read the full review here.

6) NATO

Written by Sten Rynning. Published in New Haven, CT by Yale University Press.

International Affairs’ first Review Forum of 2024 provides an in-depth appraisal of Sten Rynning’s timely book NATO: from Cold War to Ukraine, a history of the world’s most powerful alliance. In the forum, four experts examine Rynning’s accessible history of the alliance, the author’s understanding of the most suitable role for NATO and his policy recommendations to ensure NATO remains at its best (in its classic Europe-focused format). The book does an excellent job of emphasizing the cyclical nature of NATO’s existence, from crisis to opportunities, and Rynning usefully navigates the current challenges that the alliance faces.

Read the Review Forum here.

7) Wealth, power, and authoritarian institutions

Written by Michaela Collord. Published in Oxford by Oxford University Press.

In her debut monograph, Michaela Collord develops a convincing comparison of how ruling elites, particularly party leaders, have accumulated and invested wealth with institutional repercussions for parliaments in Uganda and Tanzania. Wealth, power, and authoritarian institutions draws contrasts between the neighbouring countries, showcasing how centralized resource accumulation has hindered legislative autonomy in Tanzania and how elite enrichment has made it almost impossible to instil party discipline in Uganda. Collord offers a persuasive account of east African politics and the key individuals that, through loyalty and prestige, have successfully leveraged elite factional rivalries within their respective parliaments.

Read the full review here.

8) Post-imperial possibilities

Written by Jane Burbank and Frederick Cooper. Published in Princeton, NJ and Oxford by Princeton University Press.

If you know of Jane Burbank and Frederick Cooper, then this recommendation is hardly necessary. However, if you are not acquainted with their ground-breaking 2010 work Empires in world history, do yourself a favour: pick it up and quickly follow up with Post-imperial possibilities. Burbank and Cooper are back (and better than ever) with this exploration of three hypothetical world visions that emerged in the global South during the wave of decolonization. The book investigates the origins, premises and merits of ideas of Eurafrica, Eurasia and Afroasia as future possibilities at a time of hopeful, rapid and drastic change. The book straddles both mid-twentieth-century history and more recent developments, questioning the inevitability of the nation-state model of statehood. An original and extraordinary book.

Read the full review here.

9) The women of the far right

Written by Eviane Leidig. Published in New York by Columbia University Press.

If Cynthia Enloe was to delve into the literature on far-right radicalization and ask: ‘Where are the women?’, Eviane Leidig’s book would provide the answer. The book offers many new insights, exploring how these influencers were radicalized themselves, shedding light on the business and lifestyle dimensions of their online radicalization activities and contextualizing their impact within wider transnational networks.

Written by Lou Pingeot. Published in New York and Oxford by Oxford University Press.

item.title: Has Trump Changed?
item.description:
Juliet Kaarbo discusses Trump’s ‘changed personality’ and how it may affect his second term.

In his first press conference after the 2024 US election, President-elect Donald Trump claimed that his personality changed from his first term, and for the better. However, analysing Trump during the 2024 campaign, others have sounded alarm bells about his mental state and what that might mean for his leadership. Such speculation as to what might be different about a Trump 2.0 administration, and about Trump himself, begs the question: do leaders ever really change?

Do leaders ever change?

Research in psychology supports the idea that leaders have stable personalities. This is because their general world-views, characteristics and motivations stem from their socio-cultural backgrounds and genetic factors, which do not change over time. This has been a long-held and broadly supported view in both psychology and the subfield of political psychology.

However, some research challenges the notion that leaders are set in their ways. For example, modern personality research highlights how humans undergo personality changes during periods of transition. Studies have also shown that belief systems are more pliable than once thought, and that leaders can experience significant changes. Moreover, power itself alters us, even neurologically, often generating more self-confidence, self-entitlement and self-serving behaviours.

Has Trump changed since 2016?

So, what about Trump? Were four years of presidency enough to change him? Consistent with the ‘people are stable’ view, we would not expect Trump’s second term to be dramatically different to his first. Indeed, some of the traits that Trump displayed in his first presidency, such as his intense distrust of others and ultra-sensitivity to criticism, in addition to his tendency to challenge or ignore norms and his transactional and ‘America First’ world-views, continue to reflect in his words and actions today.

Yet, key developments could have changed Trump. For one, Trump is not as politically inexperienced as he was when he first took office. Thus, there is a possibility that he may be even less likely to listen to advice this time around. Furthermore, at 78, Trump may be experiencing age-related changes, perhaps thinking in short time horizons, reflecting on mortality, or experiencing the psychological effects of age-related medical conditions. While old age does not affect all people in the same way, we might expect cognitive decline, heightened emotionality and an increased focus on legacy, which could lead to more risk-taking and authoritarian practices. For example, Trump 2.0’s references to ‘manifest destiny’ and his threats to take Greenland may stem from a motivation to leave a legacy.

Another way Trump might have changed is in learning what did and didn’t work during his first term. For example, Trump seems to have concluded that loyalty, as a quality in his advisers, should be the predominant criterion for his appointments. We clearly see this in his new cabinet choices which have been shaped more by candidates’ devotion to Trump than by their having suitable experience for the positions, and also in the exceptional informal power Trump has granted Elon Musk. Additionally, in his first term Trump learned the constraints that bureaucracy can place on presidents. These limitations were highly incongruent with Trump’s previous experience as a CEO where he had much more autonomy. As a result, Trump learned to assert greater control over non-political appointees and independent agencies. Such centralization of authority and decision-making may intensify to avoid the frustration he experienced in his first term. We already see this in Trump’s attempts to reshape the federal bureaucracy, which have included threats to close agencies, such as USAID.

Finally, dramatic events in the first Trump administration and the inter-term period may have triggered key changes in Trump. The first impeachment trial, for example, reportedly infuriated him, affecting both his view of a ‘deep state’ within his administration and his orientation toward Ukraine. His defeat in the 2020 election, and his inability to overturn the election results, only strengthened this vengeance motive against those who he feels wronged him. For example, in the early days of his second presidency, Trump fired Justice Department personnel who were involved in January 6 investigations and also revoked federal protection for his former advisers-turned-critics. Furthermore, Trump’s success in 2024 (and his survival of two assassination attempts) may have created a strong feeling of invincibility and hubris syndrome. Trump’s bold self-confidence is evident early in his second term, and can be seen in his numerous, sweeping executive orders, extraordinary tariffs levelled against economic allies and bullying of Panama and Colombia.

A heightened version of the same Trump?

Experiences of his first presidency, changes triggered by age and key events have not generated an entirely new Trump; rather, they have reinforced his existing beliefs, characteristics and motivations. So, what we likely have now is a more extreme and experienced version of Trump 1.0. He may have always been vindictive towards those he perceived as threatening, but now he has more targets and deeper knowledge of how to use the powers of presidency.

Whether any changes in Trump’s character will affect his policy-making and governance partly depends on where he focuses his efforts. As in his first term, Trump may be predictably unpredictable regarding which policy areas and political actors attract his attention. But what we do know is that Trump 2.0 has come to office with a clearer focus on strengthening his powers and surrounding himself with like-minded people — these are the key differences thus far. How Trump interprets and builds on his experience in his second term can further alter (and reinforce) who he is, with significant consequences for the US and beyond.

Juliet Kaarbo, Professor of Foreign Policy, University of St Andrews, Leverhulme Trust Major Research Fellow.

Read more about this topic in the full article ‘New directions for leader personality research: breaking bad in foreign policy’, published in International Affairs.

item.title: Trump’s policies and actions pose serious risks to corporate America
item.description:
Trump’s policies and actions pose serious risks to corporate America Expert comment LToremark 26 September 2025

US democratic backsliding and diminished support for global norms may undermine investor confidence in the US and affect the ability of American companies to do business abroad.

Traditionally, American business has relied on the relative stability and predictability of the nation’s governance – despite the turbulence of domestic politics – and on US support for the institutions and norms underpinning the rules-based international order.

That stability is now being upended by the policies and actions of the Trump administration. This not only poses severe challenges to the US, international security and global economy but also to US multinational corporations and institutional investors. 

Related work

The biggest economic risk from Donald Trump’s presidency is a loss of confidence in US governance

President Trump’s economic policies, including much higher and deeply uncertain trade tariffs, are beginning to undermine confidence in the US as a financial ‘safe haven’. An inward-looking, protectionist US is not in the long-term interest of American companies, investors, consumers or workers – nor is a global order in which normative rules are trumped by transactional deals. 

The erosion of the rule of law in the US and arbitrary use of executive power is further weakening the predictability and transparency valued by companies and investors.

Despite this, US multinational corporations and investors are underestimating these challenges and the risks they pose to their interests. Instead of fighting to safeguard the structural bedrock of their success, most are sidestepping their responsibility. Why?

Risks to corporate America and the US economy

Even before last year’s presidential election, apprehensions were widely shared – but rarely voiced – by US business leaders. Former Merck CEO Ken Frazier warned of an existential threat to the ‘basic norms, values and respect for the rule of law that has made the American economy what it is’ and former American Express CEO Ken Chenault cautioned that ‘business requires stability’.  

But uncertainty over the election outcome – and anxiety over retribution after a Trump victory – prevented corporate America’s major policy organizations from speaking clearly about the stakes for business, the US and the world. The prospect of lower corporate taxation and regulation also provided tangible short-term prizes that outweighed hypothetical long-term risks.

Yet the response from US business has continued to be muted even as many of those risks have crystallized.

Related work

Flux in President Trump’s trade and foreign policy is the new normal. Can world leaders regain some initiative?

At home, the direction towards democratic backsliding is consistent. Abroad, the direction of the US government has been consistently ‘America First’ in tone but unpredictable in substance.

Perhaps the greatest damage to American multinationals has been the crippling of US engagement in the international community, its diplomatic capacity and soft power with the elimination of USAID and the restructuring of the State Department. The weakening of US support for multilateral institutions and agreements complicates the ability of American multinationals to follow standards and regulations across different jurisdictions. Meanwhile, the elimination of most humanitarian and development assistance programs may heighten risks of instability and conflict in many countries and regions where American and other multinationals operate.

Moreover, the degradation of initiatives to counter corruption and to protect labour and human rights undermines responsible business conduct that remains essential to business stability. As a result, US companies may become more exposed to legal challenges, operational disruptions and brand boycotts. 

Fear of speaking out

Corporate America is currently in no mood to openly challenge the Trump administration, despite private worries over ‘state capitalism’, pressure on the Fed, high new tariffs and restrictions on immigration. Indeed, American CEOs are unlikely to spark an anti-Trump rebellion anytime soon, especially with the intimidation and implied threat of retribution posed by the reported White House ’loyalty rating’ of over 500 companies and trade associations.

Corporate America’s primary public policy organization of CEOs, the Business Roundtable, remains very cautious. While it made a careful statement welcoming trade deals to lower tariffs – along with the National Association of Manufacturers and the US Chamber of Commerce – it has otherwise refrained from the kind of critical and/or constructive statements that were common during previous administrations of both parties.

Indeed, neither such organizations nor the broader US business community – most conspicuously the tech industry – have spoken out or acted to counter trends that may further corrode the pillars of the US and global economy. 

But some individual business leaders are beginning to speak out, including major US investors like Bridgewater hedge fund founder Ray Dalio. Citadel CEO (and Republican megadonor) Ken Griffen criticized Trump’s attempts to undermine the independence of the Fed. 

Legal scholars and jurists have also been influential, such as the Republican former federal judge Michael Luttig. In June, the American Bar Association (ABA) sued the Trump administration over the executive orders targeting law firms. In September, the ad hoc bipartisan group (of prominent legal scholars, public servants and literary figures) We Hold These Truths took out ads in major media outlets supporting personal freedoms, separation of powers, the rule of law, equality, democracy and elections.

A realistic and responsible approach for business 

But these actions, though significant, are insufficient. Despite their concerns, US multinationals and investors can and should go further to protect their interests and the core values that are currently under threat.

item.title: What feminism can do for cybersecurity
item.description:
Anwar Mhajne and Crystal Whetstone show why cybersecurity needs to be understood from a feminist lens.

Traditionally, within International Relations (IR) cybersecurity has often been viewed through a realist, state-centric lens as an instrument of national security. However, viewing cybersecurity as such masks its implications for human rights and human security. For instance, not only do democratic and non-democratic governments exploit this conception of cybersecurity to justify espionage, censorship, surveillance and disinformation, but they may also label criticism as ‘fake news’ and pressure businesses for access to personal data to verify it. In this context, some scholars question the utility of the term ‘cybersecurity’ itself, believing it may perpetuate militarized policies. Others suggest adopting a ‘pluriversal cybersecurity’ to encompass diverse perspectives beyond state and corporate security.

In this blogpost, we build on our International Affairs article to make the case for understanding cybersecurity from a feminist perspective. A feminist lens would help emphasize security’s multifaceted nature and provide interdisciplinary ways of thinking about cyber(in)security and violence. We show how this can be achieved by incorporating insights from feminist security studies (FSS) that can help decentre the state, shift the focus to human rights protections in cyberspace and interrogate who is served by traditional cybersecurity approaches.

What feminism can bring to cybersecurity

We use Anne Runyan’s gendered lens to develop a more comprehensive understanding of cybersecurity. This approach uses intersectionality to explore how gender, race, class and sexuality collectively influence people’s experiences under dynamic power structures and oppressions. It provides crucial insights into the everyday experiences of cyber violence, ranging from technology-facilitated gender-based violence (TF-GBV) and attacks on critical infrastructure to cyberharassment, all of which more significantly affect people from marginalized backgrounds.

A feminist cybersecurity: addressing the crisis of cyber(in)security

FSS scholars contend that security extends beyond nation-states. Rather, they expand the mainstream notion of cybersecurity by focusing on the security of ordinary individuals. This approach captures many vulnerabilities that are often overlooked in traditional discussions on cybersecurity. For example, cyberharassment, particularly TF-GBV, impacts women, children, and gender diverse and queer people and those from marginalized backgrounds to a greater degree than it impacts men and other hegemonic groups due to racialization and their status as minorities. Yet, most governments and traditional security actors do not pay enough attention to this violence, given their limited focus on state security, as seen in the US government’s national cybersecurity strategy and NATO’s cyber defence policy. Ultimately, FSS challenges this by advocating for a more inclusive understanding that accounts for the diverse and everyday cyber insecurities faced by people.

How a feminist cybersecurity can be achieved

Feminist studies scholars recommend democratizing the theory and practice of cybersecurity. They encourage acknowledging the agency of those who directly experience cyber insecurities and actively involving them in matters of peace and security without relying on militarization. For example, instead of promoting a state-centred, top-down approach to designing frameworks to ‘secure’ cyberspace, international legislation could incorporate a gendered lens that engages civil society. Such efforts can address cyber-based human rights violations while avoiding a damaging cyber arms race.

We recommend establishing a cybersecurity treaty for the protection of civil liberties and rights for all, informed by marginalized groups such as queer communities and those from the global South. Such a framework must avoid being co-opted by powerful nations and must be a participatory process that includes grassroots collaborations.

Initiatives in which the voices of marginalized communities are prioritized have proved effective in the past. For example, the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons saw great participation by those in non-nuclear states and civil society, and demonstrates the effectiveness of the involvement of the global South and civil society in crafting solid protections. A bottom-up approach could create an inclusive cybersecurity standard, moving beyond a protector/protected binary centred only on looking after users in the West and fostering genuine global cooperation in safeguarding online civil liberties.

Conclusion

Building cybersecurity from a feminist perspective involves ensuring access to cyberspace with human rights protections for all, which can be achieved through demilitarization that addresses the unique insecurities of different groups. A feminist cybersecurity framework emphasizes the rights of marginalized communities by acknowledging harms caused by disinformation, cyberbullying, suppression and TF-GBV. An FSS approach reveals often unseen violence through intersectionality and a broader understanding of security. While insecurities in the cyber(in)security crisis cannot be fully eliminated, they can be reduced by everyday individuals working to democratize cybersecurity practices.

Read more about this topic in the full article ‘A feminist cybersecurity: addressing the crisis of cyber(in)security’. It was published in the November issue of International Affairs.

A feminist cybersecurity: addressing the crisis of cyber(in)security

Anwar Mhajne is an Associate Professor of Political Science and International Studies at Stonehill College, US. Crystal Whetstone is an Assistant Professor at the Department of International Relations at Bilkent University, Turkey.

item.title: India is seeking to reset relations with the Taliban. But can this rapprochement last?
item.description:
India is seeking to reset relations with the Taliban. But can this rapprochement last? Expert comment thilton.drupal 15 October 2025

New Delhi has announced the reopening of its embassy in Afghanistan amid a sharp deterioration in relations between the Taliban and Pakistan.

Afghan Foreign Minister Amit Khan Muttaqi visited India last week, making him the most senior Taliban official to visit the country since the group re-seized power in Afghanistan in 2021. During the visit, the Indian government announced it would upgrade its technical mission in Kabul to the status of an embassy, which it had shut four years ago.

These developments are part of New Delhi’s efforts to reset its relations with the Taliban and mark a notable shift in the region’s geopolitics. Historically, India has viewed the Taliban with hostility, given the group’s extremist ideology and its close affiliation with the Pakistani military and intelligence establishment.

India supported the Northern Alliance against the Taliban during the 1996-2001 Afghan Civil War. India was then a close partner of the Western-backed government that assumed power following the US invasion of Afghanistan in 2001. In response, the Taliban and its proxies carried out attacks on Indian nationals in Afghanistan, including on the Indian embassy in Kabul in 2009 and the Indian consulate in Herat in 2014.

Following the Taliban’s seizure of power in 2021, India closed its embassy in Afghanistan and has not formally recognized the group as the official government. However, India reopened its technical mission in Kabul in 2022 and remained engaged with Afghanistan through humanitarian assistance, including providing aid following the earthquake in August. In November last year, the Taliban appointed an envoy in New Delhi and an acting consul general for its mission in Mumbai. The next month, Muttaqi met Indian Foreign Secretary Vikram Misri for talks in Dubai. 

The enemy of my enemy?

The Indian government’s shift to engaging with the Taliban is motivated by several factors. Primarily, New Delhi wants to prevent Afghanistan from re-emerging as a hub for militancy and terrorism that threatens India’s security. 

The Taliban represents a ‘lesser evil’ compared to groups such as Al-Qaeda and the Islamic State Khorasan Province (IS-KP). The Taliban has reassured India that it ‘will not allow any group to use our territory against others.’ Kabul also condemned the terrorist attack in Pahalgam in Indian-administered Kashmir in April.

This rapprochement coincides with a downturn in relations between Afghanistan and Pakistan. Islamabad has historically had close relations with the Taliban. But while Islamabad once viewed Afghanistan as a source of ‘strategic depth’ in its rivalry with India, it now increasingly views its north-western neighbour as a liability.

Muttaqi’s visit to India coincided with cross-border clashes between Afghan and Pakistani forces that reportedly left dozens dead. Pakistan accuses the Afghan Taliban of hosting the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP or Pakistani Taliban), a conglomerate of several insurgent groups that aims to overthrow the Pakistani state. 

The TTP has stepped up its attacks inside Pakistan since the Taliban returned to power in Afghanistan in 2021. Islamabad also accuses India of stoking these tensions, allegations which it denies. These tensions are rooted in the disputed status of the 2,600km Durand Line that delineates the Afghanistan-Pakistan border.

Diplomacy and development

For the Taliban, outreach to India signals an effort to break free of its diplomatic isolation and strengthen its legitimacy. It follows Russia’s decision in July to re-establish diplomatic relations with the Taliban, making it the first (and so far only) government to do so.

The Taliban also wants India to re-emerge as an important development partner for Afghanistan. It is particularly keen on securing economic assistance as Western donor support has declined since the Taliban took over following NATO’s withdrawal in 2021.

India was a major development partner for the previous Afghan government and supported several projects in the country. During a joint press conference with his Afghan counterpart, Indian External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar noted that India would maintain and repair completed projects in Afghanistan, as well committing to six new projects in the country.

Jaishankar also stated that India ‘deeply appreciated’ the invitation for ‘Indian companies to explore mining opportunities in Afghanistan’. Development assistance in the form of medical and food support and water resource management was also discussed during Muttaqi’s visit. Other topics included the potential for additional flights between New Delhi and Kabul, education and capacity building programmes, and expediting visas for Afghan nationals.

India also seeks to bolster its regional connectivity. It already relies on the Chabahar port in Iran for trade with Afghanistan and Central Asia. Improving relations with Kabul could lead to a further increase in trade between the two countries via this route, particularly after the closure of the Atari-Wagah border between India and Pakistan following hostilities between them in April-May.

Limits of rapprochement

Despite these moves, there remain limits to the rapprochement. The reopening of the Indian embassy in Kabul does not equate to the formal re-establishment of diplomatic relations between both countries. New Delhi remains averse to the Taliban’s extreme version of Deobandi Islam, which is shared by several groups that pursue an overtly anti-India agenda.

The gap in values between the governments of the two countries was evident in the notable absence of any female journalists during a press conference with Muttaqi. The decision drew the ire of Indian media and public opinion and prompted another press event where female journalists were present.

The Taliban has clamped down on women’s rights in Afghanistan, including banning their access to education and job opportunities in the country. In July, the International Criminal Court issued arrest warrants for two senior Taliban leaders (Supreme Leader Haibatullah Akhundzada and Chief Justice Abdul Hakim Haqqani) on charges of abuse against women and girls.

item.title: A ‘Drone Wall’ is needed for Europe to defend against a new threat
item.description:
A ‘Drone Wall’ is needed for Europe to defend against a new threat Expert comment sfarrell.drupa… 30 September 2025

The international reach of drones means that cooperation across Europe is essential to implement counter-drone measures against a hostile state or terrorist attacks.

Over the past week, a spate of incidents involving drone sightings over sensitive sites in Europe’s ‘home territories’ represents a concerning innovation of grey-zone activity.

Copenhagen airport was forced to close for several hours on 22 September, affecting 20,000 passengers. Two Royal Danish Air Force bases (Aalborg and Karup) were later disrupted by Unmanned Aerial System (UAS) sightings, closing the former site twice.

Similar incidents have been reported in Sweden (over the Karlskrona Archipelago), Norway (over Ørland Air Station and near Oslo Airport), Germany (over Schleswig-Holstein), and Finland (over Valajaskoski power station’s no-fly zone). Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen described the incursions as ‘the most severe attack on Danish infrastructure so far’.

The ‘capable actor’ to which the Danish incursions have been attributed has not been formally identified, yet they have readily been described as ‘hybrid’ incidents by Danish authorities.

Furthermore, Danish newspaper Ekstra Bladet alleges that Russian naval vessel Aleksandr Shabalikn had been identified off the coast of Denmark at the time, with its Automatic Identification System (AIS) disabled. Investigative journalists have also identified links between the Russian paramilitary RSB-Group and the owner of a cargo vessel which was also suspected of playing a role.

In response to the incursions, and at a commendably swift pace, the European Commission chaired a meeting of ten defence ministers on 26 September, and discussed the creation of a European ‘drone wall,’ an anti-UAS system focused on ‘detection and intervention’, according to Andrius Kubilius, the European Commissioner for Defence.

The World Today

Related work

Andrius Kubilius: NATO states need millions of drones for the day Russia might attack

These incidents are part of a wider trend of innovation in drone use. Since 2022, UAS were (arguably) employed most spectacularly during Operation SPIDERWEB by the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU). Utilizing cheap small UAS smuggled into Russia aboard civilian trucks, guided by open-source AI systems and civilian telephone networks, Ukraine was able to wreak havoc against Moscow’s strategic bomber force, targeting valuable strategic areas deep inside Russia.

SPIDERWEB was an 18-month operation of total secrecy and tremendous complexity, conducted by the most drone-proficient state in the world in the context of an existential defensive war. The recent European incursions by ‘capable actors’ appear to be an extension of other incidences of ‘grey-zone’ harassment, intended to demonstrate capability and disrupt civilian infrastructure. 

Different as they are, both incidences represent a wider trend in which the ‘near surface’ of European homelands is increasingly threatened. More concerningly still, tactics need not be confined to state actors, but could easily be co-opted by organized crime or terrorist groups. In the United Kingdom, drone incidents related to smuggling contraband into prisons have risen by 43 per cent within the last year, whilst the technology involved is developing at such a rate that the Chief Inspector for Prisons warned that prisoners could soon be ‘lifted out’ by drone.

Whether challenged by a rogue state or non-state actor, authorities must be ready to credibly respond. Given the cheap drones, open-source software and open-access control mechanisms used during SPIDERWEB, a simplistic terror attack against a city centre using a quadcopter is not difficult to conceptualize. 

A complex one, using a larger UAS to destroy an aircraft, could be devastating. Whether by adversary states today, or terrorist groups tomorrow, the trend is clear: malicious drone use within Europe’s home territories is becoming more achievable, prevalent, and dangerous. To deter such a threat, European governments should implement three key measures.

Develop and deploy a wide spectrum of C-UAS options

‘We need to look into effective means of how to destroy’, stated Mr Kubilius. Detection methods such as traditional radar are circumventable by smaller UAS, and difficult to apply universally. Therefore, a wide variety of counter-UAS (C-UAS) should be deployed.

Many options at the tactical level already exist, including devices for firing nets; electro-magnetic (EM) devices which can remotely control or disable drones; counter-drones to intercept hostile drones; directed-energy weapons (i.e. lasers); and traditional munitions (i.e. shotguns).

Not every solution will be appropriate for every situation: EM measures are typically passive, blocking off areas from all drones rather than targeting specific ones, and other methods carry obvious risks to the public. However, given the sheer variety of drones, and possible scenarios, the widest possible options should be available.

Such capabilities should be integrated within frameworks that prioritize speed of response, and give effective legal protection to their users. It is easy to buy drone interception devices, position powerful lasers, and train personnel with shotguns. It is far more difficult to effectively legislate for their safe, rapid use.

Develop robust command, control, and co-ordination structures

Given the variety of UAS and actors operating them, another challenge will be effectively co-ordinating between military and civil authorities. On Saturday, Germany’s Interior Minister, Alexander Dobrindt, announced plans to establish a German UAV defence centre, bringing together police, the federal criminal office, and the German Armed Forces.

Because of the international reach of such devices, cooperation across Europe is essential. The ‘drone wall’, suggested by Mr Kubiliuis is a promising start, but estimates of up to a year until effective establishment threaten the initiative. The deployment of French and Swedish counter-UAS troops to Copenhagen on Monday, ahead of two crucial European summits, is a welcome example of what can be achieved by co-operating at pace.

item.title: The International Affairs summer reading list 2025
item.description:
There is nothing quite like spending the summer lost within the pages of a great book — or ten. Every year, Book Reviews Editor Mariana Vieira shares her top ten books, recently reviewed in International Affairs, to help you navigate the latest titles and pick your summer reading with guaranteed success.

Explore the selection below, rich in new historical and theoretical perspectives as well as unexpected takes on global governance, which celebrate a variety of different publishers. And the cherry on top of the cake? More than half of the books are written by women, who — as the first title illustrates — have been consistently erased from the discipline.

1. Erased

Written by Patricia Owens. Published in Princeton, NJ by Princeton University Press.

For fans of Patricia Owens’s previous collaborations, Women’s international thought: a new history and Women’s international thought: towards a new canon, Erased: a history of international thought without men is a highly anticipated and entirely complimentary book. In this new book, Owens unearths the contributions of 18 women to bury any narratives of the International Relations (IR) discipline as a story of elite white men. While spotlighting their academic merits, especially on the debate around empire and race in IR, Owens also enquires about these women’s careers and lives: where were they able to secure writing opportunities? Which powerful men played a role in their personal and professional lives? This unique intellectual history covers it all.

Read the full review here.

2. Rise of the international

Edited by Richard Devetak and Tim Dunne. Published in Oxford by Oxford University Press.

Ever since Jeremy Bentham coined the term ‘international’ in eighteenth-century England, the concept has travelled far and wide, often through the imperial and colonial channels. This dynamic edited volume brings historians and theorists of International Relations (IR) into conversation to investigate the diversity of internationals, their varied conceptualizations and the different contexts that led to their emergence. The chapters are actor-driven, focusing on how several conceived of the ‘international’ and showcasing how the concept was understood, contested and developed in different socio-political spaces. The ideal book for anyone who wants to understand the ways in which the ‘international’ always remains plural.

Read the full review here.

3. Living the Asian century

Written by Kishore Mahbubani. Published in New York by PublicAffairs.

For most contemporary international affairs observers, Kishore Mahbubani needs no introduction. However, if one must be offered, this memoir is the perfect window into the life of former Singaporean diplomat and leading thinker on the role of Asian superpowers in the declining US-led international order. In Living the Asian century, Mahbubani draws on his decades of experience, including at the United Nations, to expose the US dominance in the organization and to offer sobering and inspiring advice for policy-makers from small states. Combining deeply personal experiences and anecdotes, Mahbubani’s lessons from and for diplomacy are wide-ranging and relevant for students of Asian politics and practitioners of world affairs.

Read the full review here.

4. Unexpected revolutionaries

Written by Manuela Moschella. Published in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University Press.

In this brilliant addition to the literature, former Chatham House Associate Fellow Manuela Moschella looks at how central banks’ incentives to expand their toolboxes and their scope are largely a result of imperatives for institutional adaptation. The author analyses the success stories of the United States Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank to underscore her central argument that banks’ strategic behaviour matters and that they often enact changes to build support, preserve their power and maintain their independence. An insightful and timely book in the age of political backlash against technocratic decision-making.

Read the full review here.

5. Assembly by design

Written by Olga Touloumi. Published in Minneapolis, MN by University of Minnesota Press.

What does the architecture of the United Nations headquarters tell us about the organization? According to Olga Toulomi, efforts to make the UN architecturally different from its predecessor reveal the tension between the institution’s inclusionary and exclusionary impulses. This expertly titled book turns to spatial politics to illustrate the physical shape of these impulses, as well as the relationship between the core (UN headquarters) and its periphery (the UN’s operational field). As our reviewer concludes, the UN site confirms that ‘while the UN’s global interior is designed to speak to the world, it has a limited capacity to listen to it’.

Read the full review here.

6. Good victims

Written by Roxani Krystalli. Published in Oxford by Oxford University Press.

If a book makes it to the British International Studies Association outstanding first book prize shortlist, you know it is going to be worth your time. If it also receives a stellar review in International Affairs, then you should be wondering why you have not read it yet. In her first book, Roxani Krystalli delves into the Colombian transitional justice context to provide a ‘caring and graceful’ examination of what it means to be a good victim in the eyes of the institutions and bureaucracies that dispatch justice in post-conflict settings. Krystalli’s exploration of the performative aspects of victimhood draws on more than 150 interviews to render visible the institutional expectations, costs and dangers of discreet identities of ‘good’ and ‘bad’ victims, in a contribution to feminist studies that will not disappoint.

Read the full review here.

7. The derecognition of states

Written by Gëzim Visoka. Published in Ann Arbor, MI by Michigan University Press.

The criteria for state sovereignty and state recognition have been widely debated in the disciplines for decades. But what about derecognition? In this open-access book, Gëzim Visoka draws on five case-studies to explain why states withdraw recognition, what rationales they offer and what regional consequences these processes can have. From Kosovo to Taiwan and Western Sahara, the examples showcase the complex interplay of political, strategic and diplomatic factors that drive derecognition efforts. As these states have found out the hard way, meeting statehood (or sovereignty) criteria is far less important than other geopolitical developments. A seemingly counter-intuitive yet entirely compelling argument, considering this book’s evidence.

Read the full review here.

8. Asia after Europe

Written by Sugata Bose. Published in Cambridge, MA by Belknap Press.

If Mahbubani thinks the twenty-first century is shaping up to be Asian, Sugata Bose’s sweeping narrative reminds readers that those on the continent were far from inward-looking in the twentieth century. To underline this argument, Asia after Europe draws on the interconnections between a cast of (Asian) characters and colonial history, from a Parsi trader’s role in the Opium Wars to Mahatma Gandhi’s solidarity with Muslims after the fall of the Ottoman empire. Bose’s fresh interpretation of global history extends to other familiar episodes, including the 1930s Great Depression and the 1955 Bandung Conference. The result is a challenging and reflective account of the ways in which Asian international solidarity consolidated and fractured over this transformative century.

Read the full review here.

9. The soft power of non-western small states

Written by Sarina Theys. Published in Abingdon and New York by Routledge.

If Mahbubani provides practical experience of small states’ diplomacy, Sarina Theys turns to Bhutan and Qatar to challenge conventional notions of power and size. While Theys is not the first to recognize the influence of small states in global politics, her latest book offers an intersubjective understanding of smallness and identity. In other words, Theys takes into consideration Bhutan’s and Qatar’s efforts regarding identity projection, mapping out their multiple identities before observing how these efforts translate (or fail to translate) into soft power influence. Overall, this is an empirically rigorous and conceptually innovative book that pushes the boundaries of western-centric literature. Check out our review for additional insights on the rather serendipitous case-study selection.

Read the full review here.

10. Securing peace in Angola and Mozambique

Written by Miranda Melcher. Published in London by Bloomsbury.

Every so often, a debut book makes its way onto our list of recommendations: this unassuming monograph is certainly worth the attention of students and scholars of peace and conflict studies. Drawing on United Nations archives and original interviews with a variety of relevant actors, Miranda Melcher offers a comprehensive analysis of two complete peace processes to expand readers’ knowledge of how to negotiate and implement a peace treaty. There is ample merit in Melcher’s comparative approach, especially as the civil wars in Angola and Mozambique allow for a significant reflection on lessons learned, including the importance of a balance between specificity and flexibility in peace deals.

Read the full review here.

Mariana Vieira is the Book Reviews Editor of International Affairs.

Find the latest book reviews section in our July 2025 issue here.

For more reading suggestions, check out the IA Bookshelf series.

If you are interested in reviewing a book for the journal, register your interest in our book review application form here.

All views expressed are individual not institutional.

The International Affairs summer reading list 2025 was originally published in International Affairs Blog on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

item.title: Top 5 books: May 2025
item.description:
Unless you live near the Equator or at the geographical poles, Spring can be an unpredictable season (especially in the UK’s island of rain). Unlike the weather, the enjoyment of books in this selection from the May 2025 issue of International Affairs is far from uncertain. While two excellent additions to the literature on the politics of victimhood in Colombia bookend this assortment curated by Book Reviews Editor Mariana Vieira, it also features cutting-edge research on the far right’s manifest destiny and on US and EU foreign policy-making.

1) Good victims

Written by Roxani Krystalli. Published in Oxford by Oxford University Press.

If a book makes it to the British International Studies Association outstanding first book prize shortlist, you know it is going to be worth your time. If it also receives a stellar review in International Affairs, then you should be wondering why you have not read it yet. In her first book, Roxani Krystalli delves into the Colombian transitional justice context to provide a ‘caring and graceful’ examination of what it means to be a good victim in the eyes of the institutions and bureaucracies that dispatch justice in post-conflict settings. Krystalli’s exploration of the performative aspects of victimhood draws on more than 150 interviews to render visible the institutional expectations, costs and dangers of discreet identities of ‘good’ and ‘bad’ victims, in a contribution to feminist studies that will not disappoint.

Read the full review here.

2) The EU High Representative

Written by Niklas Helwig. Published in Cham, Switzerland by Palgrave Macmillan.

When the Treaty of Lisbon entered into force in 2009, it provided for the appointment of the very first EU High Representative/Vice-President (HRVP). Combining two previous roles, the foreign policy chief and the vice-presidency of the European Commission, the Guardian described the role as ‘less senior, but more powerful’. Three EU HRVPs later, Niklas Helwig has taken on the challenge of comparing and assessing their mandates to ascertain which factors increase or restrain the HRVP’s effectiveness. In his ‘thoughtful exploration’, Helwig considers institutional constraints, leadership styles and the incumbent’s ability to leverage resources while navigating member-state interests as well as external challenges. Anyone interested in Europe’s role on the global stage will benefit greatly from this unassuming book.

Read the full review here.

3) World of the right

Written by Rita Abrahamsen, Jean-François Drolet, Michael C. Williams, Srdjan Vucetic, Karin Narita and Alexandra Gheciu. Published in Cambridge by Cambridge University Press.

If you think that the far right is simply an outgrowth of socio-economic alienation, this star-studded line-up of leading scholars urges you to think again. World of the right immerses readers in this cosmos, demonstrating that the political ambitions of far-right leaders are informing a ‘globally interconnected political and cultural alliance, committed to charting an illiberal and radically conservative future for the world’. Drawing on the appropriation of Antonio Gramsci’s work, the authors trace the radical right’s multilayered attempts to build its ‘own brand of hegemony’. From training and educating a global elite to cutting across North/South divides, the far-right international alliance makes an exceptionally timely object of study.

Read the full review here.

4) The end of engagement

Written by David M. McCourt. Published in New York by Oxford University Press.

In 2021, David McCourt wrote an article for International Affairs outlining how the different national security fields in the UK, US and Australia produced different framings of China’s rise. McCourt’s latest book builds on this political sociological approach and extends his effort to add nuance to our understanding of two knowledge communities that feature prominently in the US national security context: the China and the Russia watchers. The book benefits from McCourt’s almost 200 interviews with individuals from these two groupings, to report on how three dynamics eroded US engagement policies with China and Russia in widely different ways. Moving away from the focus on top-level government advisers, McCourt’s framework bridges the gap between scholars and practitioners in a book that will appeal to both audiences.

Read the full review here.

5) Born of war in Colombia

Written by Tatiana Sanchez Parra. Published in New Brunswick, NJ by Rutgers University Press.

Typically, a books blog of this kind will prioritize showcasing the spread of our book reviews’ coverage. Exceptionally, we are returning to the Colombian post-conflict society to provide a fascinating companion read to Krystalli’s monograph. In this eye-opening account, Tatiana Sanchez Parra adopts a narrative voice to foreground the experiences of forced motherhood and reproductive violence and the political struggles of women and their children born of war. Sanchez Parra’s anthropological attention to these victims underscores the limitations of a ‘past-oriented and harm-centered model of transitional justice’ whereby ‘the gendered ways in which conflict continues to remake their lives, beyond sexual violence, fall largely outside the scope of the machinery of transitional justice’. An absorbing read.

Read the full review here.

item.title: Top 5 books: September 2024
item.description:
As the new academic year kicks off, Book Reviews Editor Mariana Vieira returns with the highlights from the September 2024 issue of International Affairs. All issues of the journal feature a comprehensive book reviews section, which surveys the latest writing on international politics. The titles below spotlight appraisals of the Women, Peace and Security agenda as well as of the British empire, and new writing on the often-overlooked impact of everyday foreign policy in Russia and India.

1) Governing the feminist peace

Written by Paul Kirby and Laura J. Shepherd. Published in New York by Columbia University Press.

Beyond its brilliantly illustrated cover, this co-authored book has a much wider appeal. Paul Kirby and Laura Shepherd have teamed up for a provocative and convincing critique of the Women, Peace and Security (WPS) agenda, as a product of specific global governance frameworks. Deploying some impressive empirical research, Governing the feminist peace persuasively highlights the incoherent, contested and contingent nature of the WPS discourse, particularly as it features in the fields of policy and governance. In the words of our reviewer: ‘forgetting WPS, in the way that Kirby and Shepherd suggest, might provide an opportunity to expand the ethical imaginaries of war and peace’.

Read the full review here.

2) Empireworld

Written by Sathnam Sanghera. Published in New York by Viking Press.

With Empireworld, British journalist Sathnam Sanghera has delivered an outstanding sequel to Empireland (New York: Viking Press, 2021), exploring the impact of the British empire around the globe. Drawing on the colonial legacies in India, Barbados, Mauritius and Nigeria, the author sheds light on how Modi instrumentalizes imperialism in his electoral campaign; how former centres of the slave trade are demanding reparations; and how Nigerian democracy embodies the contradictions of empire. This lucid and accessible examination of the imperial spread of white supremacist ideas, and the mixed record of democracy promotion, will benefit those interested in British history as well as those working in diplomacy.

Read the full review here.

3) Everyday foreign policy

Written by Elizaveta Gaufman. Published in Manchester by Manchester University Press.

Russia’s invasion of Crimea and its subsequent war in Ukraine has inspired a cottage industry of books on both countries. And yet, Elizaveta Gaufman has identified a significant gap when it comes to the complex intersection of Russian foreign policy with daily life. Combining seven thematic case-studies with interviews, Everyday foreign policy examines Russia’s (in)effectiveness in spreading its values throughout society. The book uncovers the role of both hard and soft power while accounting for how ordinary Russians have experienced ‘their country’s turn to extreme nationalism over the last decade’.

Read the full review here.

4) Cosmopolitan elites

Written by Kira Huju. Published in Oxford by Oxford University Press.

Connoisseurs of Kira Huju’s 2022 International Affairs article, ‘Saffronizing diplomacy: the Indian Foreign Service under Hindu nationalist rule’, will find Huju’s first book eminently rewarding. In Cosmopolitan elites, Huju picks up the Indian Foreign Service (IFS) once again, to expose how class, caste, gender and religion shape its composition. The author brings in everyday practices and domestic hierarchies to illustrate the exclusionary codes that dictate participation in international society. The book benefits from a broad historical scope that allows Huju to document the enduring tension between the influence of colonial ideals and the aspirations of a postcolonial India.

Read the full review here.

5) Memory fragmentation from below and beyond the state

Edited by Anne Bazin, Emmanuelle Hébert, Valérie Rosoux and Eric Sangar. Published in Abingdon and New York by Routledge.

No reading list is complete — this year at least — without the latest writing on memory politics. This excellent edited volume offers 17 chapters dedicated to two different logics of memory fragmentation: vertical and horizontal. The former focuses on conflict memory discourses resulting from how political communities use the past differently, whereas the latter maps out discourses that transcend national boundaries. The book’s sections are helpfully divided according to four different types of (largely non-state) actors that can shape memory discourses. Despite the limited geographical focus on European case-studies, this is a great addition to the literature; the contributions on the role of gender and women in memory are especially welcome.

Read the full review here.
